pull.title: build: set OSX_MIN_VERSION to 10.15
pull.body:
Taken out of #20744, as splitting up some of the build changes was mentioned [here](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/22937#discussion_r707303172).

This is required to use `std::filesystem` on macOS, as support for it only landed in the libc++.dylib shipped with 10.15. So if we want to move to using `std::filesystem` for `23.0`, this bump is required.

See also: https://developer.apple.com/documentation/xcode-release-notes/xcode-11-release-notes

> Clang now supports the C++17 \<filesystem\> library for iOS 13, macOS 10.15, watchOS 6, and tvOS 13.

macOS 10.15 was released in October 2019. macOS OS's seem to have a life of about 3 years, so it's possible that 10.14 will become officially unsupported by the end of 2021 and prior to the release of 23.0.

Guix builds:
```bash
bash-5.1# find guix-build-$(git rev-parse --short=12 HEAD)/output/ -type f -print0 | env LC_ALL=C sort -z | xargs -r0 sha256sum
abc8b749be65f1339dcdf44bd1ed6ade2533b8e3b5030ad1dde0ae0cede78136  guix-build-a43b8e955558/output/dist-archive/bitcoin-a43b8e955558.tar.gz
1edcc301eb4c02f3baa379beb8d4c78e661abc24a293813bc9d900cf7255b790  guix-build-a43b8e955558/output/x86_64-apple-darwin19/SHA256SUMS.part
e9dbb5594a664519da778dde9ed861c3f0f631525672e17a67eeda599f16ff44  guix-build-a43b8e955558/output/x86_64-apple-darwin19/bitcoin-a43b8e955558-osx-unsigned.dmg
11b23a17c630dddc7594c25625eea3de42db50f355733b9ce9ade2d8eba3a8f3  guix-build-a43b8e955558/output/x86_64-apple-darwin19/bitcoin-a43b8e955558-osx-unsigned.tar.gz
257ba64a327927f94d9aa0a68da3a2695cf880b3ed1a0113c5a966dcc426eb5e  guix-build-a43b8e955558/output/x86_64-apple-darwin19/bitcoin-a43b8e955558-osx64.tar.gz
```

events.body:
Concept ACK.

Also it will make the `make deploy` [bug](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/20422#issuecomment-919012839) on macOS 10.14.6 outdated :)

> Also it will make the make deploy bug on macOS 10.14.6 outdated :)

I've commented on that PR. Given what you've posted it's not exactly clear that is a bug.

This is required to use std::filesystem on macOS as support for it only
landed in the libc++ dylib shipped with 10.15.

See also: https://developer.apple.com/documentation/xcode-release-notes/xcode-11-release-notes

events.message:
build: set OSX_MIN_VERSION to 10.15

This is required to use std::filesystem on macOS as support for it only
landed in the libc++ dylib shipped with 10.15.

See also: https://developer.apple.com/documentation/xcode-release-notes/xcode-11-release-notes

Clang now supports the C++17 <filesystem> library for iOS 13, macOS 10.15, watchOS 6, and tvOS 13.

events.body: There was an odd native windows CI failure, which I re-ran: https://cirrus-ci.com/task/6041484689408000

> There was an odd native windows CI failure, which I re-ran: https://cirrus-ci.com/task/6041484689408000

It's a network failure
```
https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases/download/v7.1.0/PowerShell-7.1.0-win-x86.zip: WinHttpReceiveResponse() failed: 12030
```
which happens sometimes.

ACK a43b8e955558483d8893996cc3a67bc74cbaf358

#### Guix build:
```
$ env HOSTS='x86_64-apple-darwin19' ./contrib/guix/guix-build
$ find guix-build-$(git rev-parse --short=12 HEAD)/output/ -type f -print0 | env LC_ALL=C sort -z | xargs -r0 sha256sum
abc8b749be65f1339dcdf44bd1ed6ade2533b8e3b5030ad1dde0ae0cede78136  guix-build-a43b8e955558/output/dist-archive/bitcoin-a43b8e955558.tar.gz
1edcc301eb4c02f3baa379beb8d4c78e661abc24a293813bc9d900cf7255b790  guix-build-a43b8e955558/output/x86_64-apple-darwin19/SHA256SUMS.part
e9dbb5594a664519da778dde9ed861c3f0f631525672e17a67eeda599f16ff44  guix-build-a43b8e955558/output/x86_64-apple-darwin19/bitcoin-a43b8e955558-osx-unsigned.dmg
11b23a17c630dddc7594c25625eea3de42db50f355733b9ce9ade2d8eba3a8f3  guix-build-a43b8e955558/output/x86_64-apple-darwin19/bitcoin-a43b8e955558-osx-unsigned.tar.gz
257ba64a327927f94d9aa0a68da3a2695cf880b3ed1a0113c5a966dcc426eb5e  guix-build-a43b8e955558/output/x86_64-apple-darwin19/bitcoin-a43b8e955558-osx64.tar.gz
```

Welcome to the yearly MacOSX bump :smile: 
I guess that's a fact of life, Apple is kind of harsh with regard to backward/forward compatibility (so many quasi-arbitrary changes every release, no beginning in trying to support all combinations), and besides, MacOS users don't seem to mind.
Concept ACK.

<!--e57a25ab6845829454e8d69fc972939a-->

The following sections might be updated with supplementary metadata relevant to reviewers and maintainers.

<!--174a7506f384e20aa4161008e828411d-->
### Conflicts
Reviewers, this pull request conflicts with the following ones:

* [#22392](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/22392) (scripts: use LIEF for ELF security & symbol checks by fanquake)

If you consider this pull request important, please also help to review the conflicting pull requests. Ideally, start with the one that should be merged first.

> Welcome to the yearly MacOSX bump 
> I guess that's a fact of life, 

At least this time it's also in aide of a larger project goal, which is the migration to `std::filesystem`.

issue.title: scripts: use LIEF for ELF security & symbol checks
issue.body:
This finishes the transition to using LIEF for the ELF symbol and  security checks.

Note that there's currently a work around used for identifying RISCV binaries (just checking the interpreter). I've sent a PR upstream, https://github.com/lief-project/LIEF/pull/562, and we should be able to drop that when using LIEF 0.12.0 and onwards.

ACK a43b8e9

I have checked that any instances of `*-darwin18` have been updated to `*-darwin-19`, also CI is green .

In terms of timing, it is likely that macOS 10.14 will be depricated around the time that `23.0` is released. This [table](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MacOS_version_history#Releases) confirms the typical lifetime of around 3 years. Additionally, I've noticed other applications I use start to phase out 10.14 support.

Guix Hashes, mine match all posted hashes
```
find guix-build-$(git rev-parse --short=12 HEAD)/output/ -type f -print0 | env LC_ALL=C sort -z | xargs -r0 sha256sum
```

issue.title: Use std::filesystem. Remove Boost Filesystem & System
issue.body:
This PR replaces our Boost Filesystem usage with [`std::filesystem`](https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/filesystem) and includes dropping Boost System as a dependency. It includes a squashed down version of the changes from #19245. 

[A macro has been added](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/commit/7002c4ade0148c3273659208ae517b79822b289d), modelling how we check for `-latomic` to facilitate linking with `-lstdc++fs` when required. This is  ~GCC < 9.1 & ~Clang < 9.0, however not always. i.e you could be using Clang 7 on top of a GCC 9 installation (i.e Ubuntu Focal) and use `<filesystem>` without passing any additional arguments. I've tested this with GCC 8 on Bionic, Clang 7 on Focal & with Apple Clang 12.0.0 on macOS.

Guix build:
```bash
bash-5.1# find guix-build-$(git rev-parse --short=12 HEAD)/output/ -type f -print0 | env LC_ALL=C sort -z | xargs -r0 sha256sum

ad7df4d8026d5bcce1321cdccc2e1820e8a8bb7e1064ed16e20a7ea354057fd2  guix-build-07269321f38e/output/arm64-apple-darwin/bitcoin-07269321f38e-osx-unsigned.dmg
```

issue.title: Backport upstream macOS build changes from 2021
issue.body:
- https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/19683
- https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/21457
  - This will conflict with our own `native_clang` pinning, so will take some work to handle (especially dealing with differing Clang versions between the macOS SDK and the version we pin for everything else), but it should nicely reduce the delta between our `depends` build system and upstream.
- https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/21793
- https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/19817
- https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/22993
  - This will raise the min SDK from 10.14 to 10.15.

These changes will bring us up to date with upstream as of September 2021. The next change after that is M1 support (#4405).

labels.name: C-upstream-port
labels.description: Category: Changes that are ported from the Bitcoin Core codebase.
